channel.title: Magnets in my house?
channel.description: Hey i got bored and took apart a old speaker i had and found a magnet in it, so i started playing with it and making other metal things magnetic like screw drivers and what not, so im wondering were i can find a really strong magnet in my house.

item.title: Magnets in my house?
item.dc:creator: @zez1ma_boy zez1ma boy
item.description:
@zez1ma_boy wrote:

[quote=“I Vain I”][quote author=John459 link=topic=469176.msg3432315#msg3432315 date=1292456083]

[/quote]
Not a real magnet. <.<

Everyone knows Asians have computers in their heads.

Computers = magnetic.

Magnets aren’t attracted, nor repelled from his head.

Thus !magnet.[/quote]

Computers wouldn’t have a good magnet in them, considering if you put a magnetic pull on hard drive, it fucks it up.

Read full topic

item.title: Magnets in my house?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

deans1243:

ooh lool, i did it and all it did was burn my finger kinda, but i only had ab out 7 inches of wire all together and probably a almost dead AA battery

Wire was not coated with the enamel stuff then. Its more of a special wire that you will need, since metal touching metal conducts, you cant have it short-circuted at all… Sounds like that’s exactly what happened.

Read full topic

item.title: Magnets in my house?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

deans1243:

vain tell me how to make the magnet with a nail copper wire and a battery i have all 3 haha. wire from the speaker nail from a picture hanging set battery from remote.

It will not be a very strong magnet, but the concept is to wrap the wire around the nail as much as possible. This cannot be done with anything less than 4 feet of wire, as it takes alot of wire to make a strong enough field to give it a magnetic “charge”. Make sure to leave about 2-3 inches for the positive and negative connections. After you are done wrapping the nail with the copper wire, put the 2 ends on a battery. If the battery is strong enough, it will A> short out (meaning the wire is not a coated wire, even though it doesn’t have plastic, does not mean its not coated, some have a special filament around them). Or it will B> Give the nail some magnetic properties.

I did this in my electronics class a while back to nearly every screwdriver we had, since most of them that had magnets, did not even hold a small screw onto them anymore.

Read full topic

item.title: Magnets in my house?
item.dc:creator: @John459 John459
item.description:
@John459 wrote:

[quote=“I Vain I”][quote author=John459 link=topic=469176.msg3432325#msg3432325 date=1292456577]

Not a real magnet. <.<

Everyone knows Asians have computers in their heads.

Computers = magnetic.

Magnets aren’t attracted, nor repelled from his head.

Thus !magnet.

But there’s two !magnets, so that is a double negative, and we all know a double negative makes a positive.
[/quote]But if it was positive, the two !magnets would repel themselves and they are two close to be repelling.[/quote]

They are repelling each other as you can see he is holding them apart from each other. If he could he’d hold them both in one hand.

Read full topic

@deans1243 wrote:

Electric motors will not give very powerful magnets, and are more of a hassle to take apart than worth. I already mentioned old HDD's though lol.
yea i couldn't find a screw driver that fit the weird ass screw to i got these like heavy duty scissors used for cutting mettle and like 20 minutes later i had my magnet:) it was kinda small but it was pretty strong it took my like 5 minutes getting it off the piece of mettle it was on lol.
